page.title: 02ROYAL AIR FORCE UPWOOD
page.content: An airfield was first built in 1917, but only lasted for 2 years before it became farmland again. It was rebuilt in 1937 as a base for light bomber squadrons. During World War II Upwood's role was operational training, and over 1500 aircrew were trained here. The station was attacked seven times but without serious damage. In 1961 Upwood ceased to be a flying base and took on an educational role for the R.A.F. A few years ago the R.A.F. moved out and the base is now the property of the U.S.A.F. Whenever the school has a sports day the children are divided into four teams named after Upwood's favourite aircraft: the York, Anson, Canberra and Lancaster. by Mr. J. Sockett
